Order Capital Round 1 (Codeforces Round 1038, Div. 1 + Div. 2) Editorial
By ahsoltan, history, 5 months ago,

2122A - Greedy Grid

Solution

2122A - Greedy Grid

If n=1n=1 or m=1m=1, there's only one down/right path, so it is trivially greedy and maximal.

If n=m=2n=m=2, any path must choose between two neighbors after the first step. Clearly, moving greedily always leads to a maximal path.

In all other cases, such a grid does exist. Assuming n≤mn≤m, start with an n×mn×m grid filled with ones, and modify the top-left 2×32×3 subgrid as follows:

[132131].[123311].
It's easy to verify that in this grid, no greedy path achieves the maximum possible value.

Bonus

Solve the problem for when the integers have to be in the range [1,k][1,k] for some kk.

2122B - Pile Shuffling

Solution

2122B - Pile Shuffling

Let's start by finding a lower bound on the number of required operations.

For each pile, we determine the minimum number of elements that must be removed from the top:

  • If bi>dibi>di, we need to remove all the zeros above before we can remove the excess ones at the bottom. So, we must remove at least ai+bi−diai+bi−di elements.
  • Otherwise, if ai>ciai>ci, we need to remove at least ai−ciai−ci zeros to reach the target number of zeros.

Summing these values over all piles gives us a clear lower bound on the total number of operations.

This lower bound is also achievable. For each element that needs to be removed, there always exists a pile where we can place it so that it never has to be moved again. Here's why:

  • If we remove a one, it's because there are too many ones in its current pile. That means there must be another pile ii with fewer than didi ones, where we can place it beneath all existing elements.
  • If we remove a zero, we can place it in any pile ii that currently has fewer than cici zeros above at most didi ones. If we place it in the highest position with at most didi ones below it, it will not need to be moved again.
Bonus

Solve the problem for multisets faster than O(n3)O(n3).

2122C - Manhattan Pairs

Solution

2122C - Manhattan Pairs

Let's begin by considering the 1D version of the problem.

In one dimension, the optimal strategy is to pair the smallest n2n2 values with the largest n2n2 values.

Now, let's move to the 2D case. The Manhattan distance is the independent sum of the contributions from the xx-coordinates and the yy-coordinates. Therefore, if we find a matching that is optimal independently for both the xx- and yy-coordinates, it will also be optimal in 2D.

To achieve this, partition the set of points in two different ways:

  • Let XlXl and XrXr be the sets of points with the smallest and largest n2n2 xx-coordinates, respectively.
  • Let YlYl and YrYr be the sets of points with the smallest and largest n2n2 yy-coordinates, respectively.

A pairing will be optimal in both dimensions if:

  • each point in XlXl is paired with a point in XrXr,
  • each point in YlYl is paired with a point in YrYr.

To satisfy both conditions simultaneously, we can pair:

  • each point in Xl∩YlXl∩Yl with a point in Xr∩YrXr∩Yr,
  • each point in Xl∩YrXl∩Yr with a point in Xr∩YlXr∩Yl.

Let aa, bb, cc, dd denote the sizes of these four groups, respectively. Note that they are disjoint. Then, we have:

  • a+c=b+da+c=b+d, because |Xl|=|Xr||Xl|=|Xr|,
  • a+d=b+ca+d=b+c, because |Yl|=|Yr||Yl|=|Yr|.
Adding these equations up yields a=ba=b and c=dc=d, so such a pairing is always possible.

2122D - Traffic Lights

Solution

2122D - Traffic Lights

Let's first construct a solution, then analyze its runtime.

Let f(i,j)f(i,j) denote the minimum waiting time to reach vertex ii at time jj. Initially, f(1,0)=0f(1,0)=0. There are two possible transitions:

  • f(i,j+1)←f(i,j)+1f(i,j+1)←f(i,j)+1,
  • f(k,j+1)←f(i,j)f(k,j+1)←f(i,j), where kk is the opposite vertex of the (jmoddeg(i)+1)(jmoddeg⁡(i)+1)-th edge of ii.

Let xx be the minimum total time required to move the token from vertex 11 to vertex nn. Then, the minimum waiting time is f(n,x)f(n,x). Thus, it suffices to compute f(i,j)f(i,j) for all j≤xj≤x, which can be done in O(nx+m)O(nx+m) time.

Observe that if there exists a path from vertex 11 to vertex nn, and the sum of the degrees of the vertices on this path is dd, then x≤dx≤d, as the worst case strategy implies waiting for the very last edge whenever advancing to a new node.

We will now show that there exists a path from vertex 11 to vertex nn such that d≤3nd≤3n.

Take any path that minimizes the number of edges from 11 to nn, that is, a shortest path. There do not exist edges between non-consecutive vertices on this path. Furthermore, there cannot exist a vertex outside this path that is adjacent to at least 44 vertices on the path, since in that case the path could be shortened.

Let the number of vertices on the path be kk. Then, the total sum of degrees is at most 2k+3(n−k)=3n−k2k+3(n−k)=3n−k, which is at most 3n3n, since k≥2k≥2.

Therefore, since x≤3nx≤3n, the solution runs in O(n2+m)O(n2+m) time.

Bonus

Prove and construct exact bound for the answer.

2122E - Greedy Grid Counting

Solution

2122E - Greedy Grid Counting

Let's examine the required condition for a single grid.

Let aiai denote the values in the top row and bibi the values in the bottom row. Define ci=ai+1−bici=ai+1−bi, and let s=a1+b1+b2+⋯+bns=a1+b1+b2+⋯+bn. Then, the value of a path that switches from the top row to the bottom row in the ii-th column is s+c1+c2+⋯+ci−1s+c1+c2+⋯+ci−1.

Let pp be the length of the longest prefix of cc such that all ci≥0ci≥0. The optimal greedy path is to follow this prefix and switch rows at column p+1p+1. Therefore, the condition holds if and only if the sum of this prefix is maximal among all prefixes. This is equivalent to requiring that every subarray of cc with left end equal to p+1p+1 has a non-positive sum.

How can we ensure this condition holds for all subgrids? We define a dynamic programming approach over the sequence cici. Let f(i,j)f(i,j) represent the number of ways to construct a valid prefix of length ii with cumulative sum jj since the most recent negative cici. The key constraint is that jj must always remain ≤0≤0 (except within the initial prefix where all ci≥0ci≥0).

Since each negative cici resets the sum, and we always have ci≥−kci≥−k, the cumulative sum jj lies within the range [−k,0][−k,0]. The transitions are straightforward: we iterate over the next element in the sequence cici and update jj based on whether cici is non-negative (accumulate) or negative (reset).

This yields an O(nk2)O(nk2) solution.

Bonus

Solve the problem in O(nk)O(nk).

2122F - Colorful Polygon

Solution

2122F - Colorful Polygon

We begin by solving the problem for the case n=2n=2.

Through experimentation, we can discover that a polygon consisting of two adjacent line segments with a+1a+1 and b+1b+1 points respectively has exactly (a+bb)(a+bb) triangulations.

Polygon with (62)=15(62)=15 triangulations.

We now generalize this construction to handle any product of binomial coefficients. The key insight is to connect these basic shapes in a manner that ensures their triangulations remain independent.

To achieve this, we extend the shorter side of the polygon to form a rectangle with additional points on two sides. This modification preserves the number of triangulations.

To connect multiple rectangles, we join them using triangular connectors, alternating the sides to which they are attached:

These connectors do not affect the total number of triangulations, as there is exactly one way to triangulate each connector.

Returning to the original problem, the most straightforward approach is to represent the required number of triangulations as a product of binomial coefficients:

(a1+⋯+ana1)(a2+⋯+ana2)⋯(anan).(a1+⋯+ana1)(a2+⋯+ana2)⋯(anan).
However, this representation requires Θ(n⋅s)Θ(n⋅s) vertices, where s=a1+⋯+ans=a1+⋯+an, which exceeds the given constraint.

To reduce the vertex count, we employ a divide-and-conquer approach, analogous to polynomial multiplication with bounded degree sum.

We can interpret the multinomial coefficient as the number of ways to assign ss elements to nn distinct colors, where color ii appears exactly aiai times. The construction procedure follows these steps:

  • First, determine the positions where the first ⌊n/2⌋⌊n/2⌋ colors will appear.
  • Recursively construct representations for the first and second halves of the color set.

This divide-and-conquer strategy reduces the vertex count to Θ(slogn)Θ(slog⁡n), which satisfies the problem constraints.

Bonus

Write a checker for this problem.

2122G - Tree Parking

Solution

2122G - Tree Parking

Let's solve the problem for a single tree.

A tree is valid if and only if no interval contains any endpoint from its subtree. This condition allows us to approach the problem using dynamic programming. After simplification, the answer for a single tree becomes

(2n)!2ns1s2⋯sn,(2n)!2ns1s2⋯sn,
where sisi is the size of the subtree rooted at vertex ii. Therefore, calculating the sum of the answers reduces to computing the sum of 1s1s2⋯sn1s1s2⋯sn across all labeled trees with nn vertices and kk leaves.

It is a well-known result that the number of topological sorts of a tree is n!s1s2⋯snn!s1s2⋯sn. This means we only need to compute the total number of topological sorts of all trees with nn vertices and kk leaves, and then divide the result by n!n! to obtain the desired sum.

Let us now fix a topological sort and count the number of trees consistent with it. This is equivalent to counting the number of trees where each parent pi<ipi<i, and the tree has exactly kk leaves. This leads to the recurrence:

f(n,k)=f(n−1,k−1)⋅(n−k)+f(n−1,k)⋅k.f(n,k)=f(n−1,k−1)⋅(n−k)+f(n−1,k)⋅k.

It turns out (as can be verified via OEIS or other sources) that f(n,k)=A(n−1,k−1)f(n,k)=A(n−1,k−1), where A(n,k)A(n,k) is the Eulerian number counting permutations of length nn with exactly kk descents. Eulerian numbers can be computed efficiently using inclusion-exclusion in O(klogn)O(klog⁡n) time.

Taking everything into account, the final answer is

A(n−1,k−1)⋅(2n)!n⋅2n.A(n−1,k−1)⋅(2n)!n⋅2n.

Bonus

Solve the problem purely with generating functions.

After solving G, I felt that it would be easier to use OEIS for the whole problem... I don't think it's good.

The induction part (or "OEIS part") in the editorial can also be replaced with a simple bijection: Consider the DFS order, visiting the larger child earlier. Then a leaf corresponds to a descent.

        I don't know your concrete confuse. there is my idea:

        We can start by considering zeros first. Since the movement of zeros is independent of ones, we just need to check which positions are short of the corresponding number of zeros. By counting these deficits, we get the total number of moves required for zeros. Then we move on to consider ones. The movement of ones actually involves two steps: first, removing the excess ones, and second, moving all the zeros above them. In this process, the minimum number of zeros that need to be moved is given by min(a, c).

Hilarious but I actually came up with problem D 3 years ago, proving that answer is ≤2n−3≤2n−3, but during the contest I completely forgot about this, submitting some bullshit. Here is my original proof writeup translated from Ukrainian.

We can restate problem as follows: there is an initial message in node 11; once node vv gets a message, it starts transmitting it to its neighbors in arbitrary order. What's the smallest time until the message reaches node nn?

Answer: 2n−32n−3

Solution. Consider a path on nn vertices in which vertex ii is connected only to i−1i−1 and i+1i+1.
Let each vertex ii (2≤i≤n−12≤i≤n−1) first send a message to vertex i−1i−1 and then to i+1i+1 (if it exists).
Clearly, vertex nn receives the message at the end of second 2n−32n−3.

Now we prove that every vertex is reached within 2n−32n−3 seconds.

Let SiSi be the set of reached vertices after second ii.
A vertex v∈Siv∈Si is called alive if it has at least one edge leaving SiSi.
For every v∈Siv∈Si define dv,idv,i to be the number of neighbours of vv that lie in SiSi and to which vv has not yet sent a message.

We maintain integers [ℓi,…,ri][ℓi,…,ri] such that the multiset (dv,i|v∈Si)(dv,i|v∈Si) is majorized by the sequence [ℓi,ℓi+1,…,ri][ℓi,ℓi+1,…,ri].
Initially ℓ0=r0=0ℓ0=r0=0. Let's update them as we transition to the next second.

Case 1. No new vertices are reached in second i+1i+1. Every alive v∈Siv∈Si uses one of its edges inside SiSi, so dv,i+1=dv,i−1.dv,i+1=dv,i−1. Hence the multiset is now majorized by [max(0,ℓi−1),…,ri−2,ri−1][max(0,ℓi−1),…,ri−2,ri−1]

Case 2. k≥1k≥1 new vertices get message in second i+1i+1. For a new vertex vv, dv,i+1≤(ri−ℓi+1)+(k−1)dv,i+1≤(ri−ℓi+1)+(k−1), while for an old v∈Siv∈Si, dv,i+1≤dv,i+(k−1)dv,i+1≤dv,i+(k−1). Thus the new degree multiset of alive vertices in Si+1Si+1 is majorized by [ℓi+k−1,…,ri+k−1,(ri−ℓi+1)+(k−1),…,(ri−ℓi+1)+(k−1)][ℓi+k−1,…,ri+k−1,(ri−ℓi+1)+(k−1),…,(ri−ℓi+1)+(k−1)] which itself is majorized by [ℓi+k−1,ℓi+k,…,ri+2k−1][ℓi+k−1,ℓi+k,…,ri+2k−1]

Consequently, if kiki vertices are added in second ii (either ki=0ki=0 or ki≥1ki≥1), the choices ℓi+1=ℓi+ki−1,ri+1=ri+2ki−1ℓi+1=ℓi+ki−1,ri+1=ri+2ki−1 preserve the majorization property.

Suppose not all vertices are reached after 2n−32n−3 seconds; then some vertices remain alive.
However, r2n−3=r0+∑2n−3i=1(2ki−1)=0+2(n−2)−(2n−3)=−1r2n−3=r0+∑i=12n−3(2ki−1)=0+2(n−2)−(2n−3)=−1 which is impossible. Hence every vertex is reached within 2n−32n−3 seconds.

    +3

    The tutorial is well explained but I'll try to explain it clearly. You only have to count how many elements you have to remove, because you can put each element you remove in its final position. So, iterating though each pile, if in one pile you have more 1s than target, you have to remove all the 0s and the exceeded 1s, add that to the result. If not, check the 0s, if you have more 0s than target, add the difference between initial 0s and target 0s. I hope it's more clear now.

    What I did: I sorted the points by the X and divided the points in 2 groups, the leftmost n/2 and the rightmost n/2. Then I sorted both groups by the Y and after that I paired the first point of the 1st group with the last point of the 2nd group and so on. I can't tell why that works but it was accepted.

      0

      it's actually right.

      consider you have an sorted array a[] of length 2n. you want to pair them up so that sum(|a[p[i]]-a[q[i]]|) is maximum. this condition is equal to that there aren't two pairs (a[x1] a[y1]) (a[x2] a[y2) (x1<y1,x2<y2) that x1<y1<x2<y2.

      if the p is a permutation of 1~n, q is a permution of n+1~2n, it's obviously that this condition is satisfied.

          Its like using diagonals so if I say what is the distance between x = 0 and x = 5, it'd be 5, but if we say distance between (0,0) and (5,5) ?           Tldr, we pair from the quarters opposite to each other diagonally.

      Xellos

      -10

      In a math contest, it'd most likely be about finding a tight bound, which fundamentally changes how a proof can be approached. In a programming contest, it's very very common to make something that resembles a proof but isn't one because the objective is different — you don't need to know if the bound on time is 10N10N or 2N2N, only that it should be low enough that your suboptimal code will fit into time and memory limits. You can start by writing a code and analysing it instead. You can generate many smaller graphs. Actual runtime is affected by cache efficiency here so maybe you need to optimise that, depending on your implementation — the time limit is kinda tight. You need to fit into memory. After experimenting a bit, getting rough insight into the problem, maybe you'd come up with a proof much easier.

+1

in problem C this was my approach

Spoiler

So first lets simplify the expression using the formula for max(a,b)=a+b+|a−b|2max(a,b)=a+b+|a−b|2 after simplifying we get that we need to maximise this expression.

∑allpairsp,qmax(xp,xq)+max(yp,yq)∑p,qallpairsmax(xp,xq)+max(yp,yq)

so our strategy can be to first sort all points w.r.t. xx after sorting we see that we pair 1st to last 2nd to second last, so the first part of the summation is taken care of, now we need to maximise the second part without rendering the first part useless. we notice that matching any xpxp before the median and xqxq after the median will only depend in the value of xqxq part and the sum can be same if we change the elements in any order before the median and after the median in their respective parts. so to maximise the second part we can sort the first part till n/2n/2 w.r.t. yy and the second part w.r.t. yy independently.

Here is my solution for problem D which passed system tests, but I was unable to prove it. I hope either someone will hack it or provide the proof: Let's first try to minimize total time. I just have state (i, x) for being in vertex i and trying to go on x-th edge outgoing from i. After this my assumption was that in optimal solution (considering minimizing waiting time) you never need to arrive more than n minutes late compared to earliest arrival time in any vertex. But as I said above, I was unable to prove it. Any counterexamples or insights will be appreciated.

      0

      firstly, I calculated earliest arrival time for each vertex. Then, as mentioned above, I assumed that you don't need to arrive more than n minutes later than earliest arrival time for each vertex. Now graph states become (v, t) where v is the vertex you are currently and t is time passed relative to earliest arrival for this vertex. We need to calculate minimum waiting time. We have transitions from (v,t) to (v, t+1) with cost 1, and transition to (to, current_time — D[to] + 1) with cost 0, where to is vertex where we can go and D[to] is earliest possible arrival in this vertex.As costs are 0/1 we can use 0/1BFS

            Through further reflection, I discovered that for an f(z)×g(z)f(z)×g(z), if each coefficient of g(z)g(z) can be expressed by a kk-degree polynomial, then it can be computed in O(nk2)O(nk2) time.

            Specifically, consider the target exponent s=i+js=i+j. By replacing each indeterminate in the polynomial expressing g(z)g(z)'s coefficients with ss, we obtain a coefficient polynomial for each power term. This polynomial should treat ss as the variable, with coefficients derived from the original polynomial. Ultimately, this can be transformed by incorporating the exponent into f(z)f(z) and computing the result via prefix sums. The coefficients of each prefix sum are then determined based on the exponent of each term in the resulting polynomial.

            For example, given f(z)×g(z)=h(z)f(z)×g(z)=h(z) where g(z)=∑(b+ki)zig(z)=∑(b+ki)zi, we have:

            h(z)=∑i=0nfign−i=∑i=0nfi(b+kn−ki)=∑i=0n−k(i×fi)+(b+kn)∑i=0nfih(z)=∑i=0nfign−i=∑i=0nfi(b+kn−ki)=∑i=0n−k(i×fi)+(b+kn)∑i=0nfi

            This can be computed by maintaining the prefix sums of i×fii×fi and fifi.

            When gxgx is a linear function, this approach applies. Higher-degree cases can be handled similarly.

            The translation was finished by Deepseek because my English is too terrible.

5 months ago, show #

theHope15
5 months ago, hide # |
 
0 
void solve()
{
    int n ; cin>>n;
    int cnt = 0;
    foru(n){
        int a , b, c, d;
        cin>>a>>b>>c>>d;
        if(a == c && b>d){
            cnt +=  a + b-d ;
        }
        if(a>c && b==d){
            cnt+= a-c;
        }
        if(a>c && b>d){
            cnt+= a-c + c + b -d;
        }
        if(a<c && b>d){
            cnt += a + b-d;
        }
        if(a>c && b<d){
            cnt+= a-c;
        }
    }
    
    cout<<cnt<<endl;
 
 
}

This is how i did problem number B.

+42

Here is the solution to G-Bonus (solution using purely generating functions).

if we let Tn,lTn,l represent the number of valid permutations on all labelled trees with nn vertices and "l"l leaves, and let

t(x,y)=∑∞n=0∑∞l=01(2n)!(n)!Tn,l xnylt(x,y)=∑n=0∞∑l=0∞1(2n)!(n)!Tn,l xnyl

then we have the following recurrence relation

Tn,l=∑∀ (n1,⋯,nr)n1+n2+⋯+nr=n−1n1≤n2≤⋯≤nrC(n1,⋯nr)⋅(2(n1+⋯+nr)+1)!(2 n1)!⋯(2 nr)!∑l1+⋯+lr=ll1≤n1,⋯,lr≤nrTn1,l1⋯Tnr,lrTn,l=∑∀ (n1,⋯,nr)n1+n2+⋯+nr=n−1n1≤n2≤⋯≤nrC(n1,⋯nr)⋅(2(n1+⋯+nr)+1)!(2 n1)!⋯(2 nr)!∑l1+⋯+lr=ll1≤n1,⋯,lr≤nrTn1,l1⋯Tnr,lr

where $C \left( n_1, \cdots , n_r \right)$ is the function that counts the number of partitions of 1,⋯,n1+⋯+nr+11,⋯,n1+⋯+nr+1 into sets of sizes 1,n1,n2,...,nr1,n1,n2,...,nr respectively (For example C(2,1)=4!2!1!=12C(2,1)=4!2!1!=12 and C(2,2)=5!2!2!2!=15C(2,2)=5!2!2!2!=15). In terms of generating functions, this becomes

t(x,y)=12∫et(r,s)−12r(1−s)drt(x,y)=12∫et(r,s)−12r(1−s)dr

Taking partial derivative w.r.t $x$, we get

∂(e−t(x,y))∂x=12e−12x(1−y)∂(e−t(x,y))∂x=12e−12x(1−y)

Integrating w.r.t xx, we get

t(x,y)=−ln(c(y)−e−12x(1−y)1−y)t(x,y)=−ln⁡(c(y)−e−12x(1−y)1−y)

Comparing coefficients of $x^0 y^m$ on both sides for all m≥0m≥0, we have that c(y)=y1−yc(y)=y1−y. Thus for n≥1n≥1, we have that

[xn⋅yl]t(x,y)=[xn⋅yl]{−ln(1−e−12x(1−y)y)}=[xn⋅yl]{∑∞m=11me−m2x(1−y)ym}[xn⋅yl]t(x,y)=[xn⋅yl]{−ln(1−e−12x(1−y)y)}=[xn⋅yl]{∑m=1∞1me−m2x(1−y)ym}

Expanding this further, we get

[xn⋅yl]{∑∞m=0∑∞r=01m(−1)rmr2r⋅r!xr(1−y)r1ym}[xn⋅yl]{∑m=0∞∑r=0∞1m(−1)rmr2r⋅r!xr(1−y)r1ym}

We must have $r=n$ and r−m=lr−m=l to get the required coefficient. Substituting this we get

∑∞m=0mn−1(−1)n2n n!(nm+l)(−1)m+l=(−1)n+l2n n!∑∞m=0(−1)mmn−1(nm+l)∑m=0∞mn−1(−1)n2n n!(nm+l)(−1)m+l=(−1)n+l2n n!∑m=0∞(−1)mmn−1(nm+l)

Taking k=n−m−lk=n−m−l, we can re-write the summation as follows

(−1)n+l2n n!∑n−lk=0(−1)n−l−kn−l−kn−1(nk)=12n n!A(n−1,n−l−1)=12n n!A(n−1,l−1)(−1)n+l2n n!∑k=0n−l(−1)n−l−kn−l−kn−1(nk)=12n n!A(n−1,n−l−1)=12n n!A(n−1,l−1)

Now, since the coefficient in t(x,y)t(x,y) is equal to Tn,l(2n)! (n)!Tn,l(2n)! (n)!, we have that

Tn,l=(2n)!2nA(n−1,l−1)Tn,l=(2n)!2nA(n−1,l−1)

Now, since the root is fixed, we must divide by $n$ to get only labelled trees having 11 as the root.
